channel.title: Science & tech | Mail Online
channel.description: Stay up-to-date with the latest science and technology news from Daily Mail including scientific discoveries, pictures, new technology, and more.

item.title: Space needs the same legal protections as land and sea to protect its fragile environment
item.description: Low Earth orbit is at risk from space debris, and objects causing light pollution for astronomers viewing space from the Earth, according to a new study led by the University of Edinburgh.

item.title: Elon Musk's SpaceX Starlink 'rapidly' fought off a Russian jamming attack in Ukraine
item.description: An official from the US Office of the Secretary of Defense said the US military would have taken much longer to counter the attack against the SpaceX network.

item.title: Viking ship discovered 30ft underground in Norway using RADAR
item.description: The discovery was made as part of archeological work on a site that could form part of the route for the proposed E39 highway, near Øyesletta, western Norway.
item.media:credit: Credit: Jani Causevic/NIKU via Pen News

item.title: Scientists reveal the most off-putting flirting tactics - including swearing and being too touchy
item.description: Scientists from the University of Nicosia have revealed the 11 most off-putting flirting tactics, which are dealbreakers for many people.

item.title: Large Hadron Collider fires up for the first time in three years
item.description: Firing up the nearly 17 mile-long LHC under Switzerland is a complex process, requiring everything to 'work like an orchestra', especially after the extended shut down due to Covid-19.

item.title: Forget robotic dogs! Scientists develop a robotic RAT that could help in search and rescue missions
item.description: Scientists from the Beijing Institute of Technology have developed a four-legged robotic rat called SQuRo (small-size quadruped robotic rat).

item.title: Indiana Jones was right! Smaller species of scorpions ARE more deadly than larger ones
item.description: Researchers from NUI Galway analysed 36 species of scorpions and found that the smallest species were over 100 times more potent that then largest.

item.title: National parks DON'T always boost biodiversity, British Ecological Society report claims
item.description: In a new report launched today, BES warns that more action is needed to meet the government's '30x30' target, which aims to protect 30 per cent of the UK's land and sea by 2030.

item.title: Meta urges Instagram users to stop sharing TikTok videos to Reels
item.description: It wants to focus on original content, giving creators the tools they need to publish directly to Reels and 'make sure credit is going to those who deserve it.'

item.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launches for 12th mission
item.description: The two-stage rocket launched at 1:51pm EDT from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, just a month after the last Starship launch to space.

item.title: Anglo-Saxon kings 'were mostly vegetarian before the Vikings settled'
item.description: Cambridge researchers argue that very few people in England ate large amounts of meat before the Vikings settled - and there is no evidence that elites ate more meat than other people.

item.title: Britons have suffered from WORMS since the Bronze Age
item.description: Oxford researchers analysed ancient skeletons in an effort to establish the size and scale of parasitic worm infections in the UK over the course of history.

item.title: NASA lunar backpack could give astronauts the ability to generate a 3D map
item.description: The Kinematic Navigation and Cartography Knapsack (KNaCK) is a mobile lidar scanner, worn as a backpack that uses light and lasers to measure range.

item.title: Disposable coffee cups shed TRILLIONS of microscopic plastic particles into your drink
item.description: Researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology analysed single-use hot beverage cups coated with a soft flexible plastic film often used as a waterproof liner.

item.title: 'Hair of the dog' tests reveal pooches that spend weeks in shelters can suffer from 'chronic stress'
item.description: Researchers from Utrecth University analysed hair samples to assess dogs' levels of cortisol - the primary stress hormone.

item.title: The secret life of humpback whales: 'Gunshot' call offers glimpse of their lives in the high seas
item.description: The team from the universities of Exeter and Stellenbosch and Greenpeace recorded sounds at the Vema Seamount in the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: Futuristic cargo drone could be used to deliver packages over distances of up to 25 miles
item.description: The uncrewed eVTOL (electric vertical takeoff and landing) aircraft is a joint design study between Austrian company CycloTech GmbH and Japan's Yamato Holdings Co. Ltd.

item.title: People who wear designer clothes are more likely to be seen as UNCOOPERATIVE, study finds
item.description: Researchers from the University of Michigan found that people who display luxury brands and other signals of status are more likely to be seen as uncooperative.

item.title: The science behind the perfect CRISP SANDWICH: Chicken Tikka and Ready Salted are best pairing
item.description: Dr Stuart Farrimond, a food scientist, reviewed the flavour compounds in popular sandwiches and crisps, in a study held at the University of Chester and commissioned by Subway and Walkers.

item.title: NASA's Perseverance rover captures stunning footage of a solar eclipse from Mars
item.description: NASA's Perseverance rover, which has been on Mars since February 2021, captured the footage with its next-generation Mastcam-Z camera on April 2.

item.title: Astronomers discover immense swarms of sunspots that could lead to solar flares
item.description: Sunspots are dark regions of the Sun where it is cooler than other parts of the surface. Solar flares originate close to these dark areas of the star.

item.title: Venus's thick atmosphere keeps the planet moving, despite the Sun's gravitational pull
item.description: Venus takes 243 Earth days to rotate, but its atmosphere circulates the planet every four days, according to the team from the University of California, Riverside.

item.title: Early human ancestors engraved images on stone tablets by firelight 15,000 years ago
item.description: The study, by researchers at the Universities of York and Durham, looked at the collection of engraved stones, known as plaquettes, which are now held in the British Museum.

item.title: Apple will now scan photos sent and received by children in the UK for NUDITY and blur them
item.description: Apple has launched its Communication Safety tool in the UK, four months after rolling it out in the US. The tool will scan images sent and received by children for nudity and automatically blur them.

item.title: Astronomers discover new kind of stellar explosion called a 'micronova'
item.description: An international team of researchers, led by Durham University, observed the phenomenon in three white dwarfs - the remnants of dead stars - as they fed in each case on a companion star.

item.title: Pterosaurs could change the colour of their FEATHERS to attract mates or keep cool
item.description: Researchers from University College Cork have carried out a new study of a 115 million year old fossilised headcrest of the the pterosaur Tupandactylus imperator from north-eastern Brazil.

item.title: Elon Musk warns that life on Mars will be dangerous, cramped and difficult
item.description: The world's richest man has been vocal about his goal of making humanity a multiplanetary species, including developing rockets to colonize Mars by 2050.

item.title: Dogs' average heart rate DOUBLES between the waiting room and the examination table at the vet
item.description: Researchers from the University of Adelaide hooked dogs up to heart rate monitors to see how they reacted during a visit to the vet.

item.title: Women feel more 'overwhelmed, stressed and frustrated' at work
item.description: Yale University-led experts found that, compared to men, women reported feeling more overwhelmed, stressed, frustrated, tense, and discouraged, and less respected and confident.

item.title: 700-year-old SHIP discovered beneath the streets of Tallinn was part of the Hanseatic League
item.description: The 80ft-long vessel, thought to be a 13th-century Hanseatic cog, was found during construction work in the Estonian captial.

item.title: Hunt is on for fallen meteorite after massive fireball is seen streaking over the west of England
item.description: Scientists from the UK Fireball Alliance (UKFAll) believe that fragments of the meteorite landed somewhere south of the market town of Shrewsbury.

item.title: Treat in store for stargazers as four planets will align in dazzling sky parade this week
item.description: Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn will form a row in the sky in a 'planet parade' that will dazzle stargazers. Experts say the best viewing window is between 5am and 6am over the coming days.

item.title: NASA urged to probe URANUS and study its gaseous atmosphere
item.description: Known as the Committee on the Planetary Science and Astrobiology Decadal Survey, it designates a Uranus Orbiter and Probe as the highest-priority flagship mission.

item.title: Hottest rock on Earth formed in temperatures that reached 4,298°F
item.description: Scientists say the fist-sized piece of black glass was formed in a meteorite impact that generated 4,298°F (2,370°C) heat when it smashed into what today is Labrador, Canada.

item.title: Artificial vision could be a reality thanks to an electric eye being developed by scientists
item.description: Georgia State University researchers created the device using a new vertical stacking system, allowing it to be scaled down, and operate at micro-levels.

item.title: Meet N.swiftae! New species of twisted-claw MILLIPEDE is named after singer Taylor Swift
item.description: Researchers from Virginia Tech have named a new species of twisted-claw millipeded, discovered in the Appalachian Mountains, Nannaria swiftae.

item.title: Holographic doctor visits the International Space Station
item.description: Flight surgeon Dr Josef Schmid was beamed to the International Space Station, where he was able to enjoy a two-way conversation with French astronaut Thomas Pesquet.

item.title: How Pegasus spyware 'found on a device connected to Number 10' works
item.description: Pegasus is sold by the Israeli-based NSO Group so governments can carry out surveillance by infecting phones with malicious software, but ordinary members of the public may also be at risk.

item.title: Scientists develop an app that can detect whether you have Covid-19 with 92 per cent accuracy
item.description: The app, called ResApp, uses machine learning to analyse the sounds of your cough. During testing, the app was found to correctly detect COVID-19 in 92 per cent of people with the infection.

item.title: Antarctic sea-ice is at a record LOW, study warns
item.description: On February 25, sea-ice levels in the Bellingshausen Sea, Amundsen Sea and the Weddell Sea hit record lows of around 30 per cent lower than the average from 1981-2010.

item.title: Boots will stop selling all wet wipes that contain plastic fibres by the end of 2022
item.description: Boots has announced that all plastic-based wet wipes will be replaced with plant-based biodegradable alternatives by the end of the year.

item.title: Netflix is launching an Exploding Kittens mobile game and TV series in a first-of-its-kind deal
item.description: Exploding Kittens - The Game will launch on Netflix in May, followed by an adult animated comedy series next year, starring Tom Ellis, Abraham Lim and Lucy Liu.

item.title: Brits cancelled more than 1.5M subscriptions to streaming services in first three months of 2022
item.description: UK households are looking for ways to curb non-essential spending to cope with rising energy, clothing and food prices, with more than half of the terminations attributed to 'money saving'.

item.title: Six of the world's smallest FROGS are discovered in Mexico
item.description: Scientists at the Natural History Museum in London, who helped to identify the six new Craugastor species, say they should be classed as endangered and called for better protection.

item.title: MailOnline tests Snap's augmented reality Spectacles that it expects everyone to be wearing by 2032
item.description: While the glasses are not for sale, MailOnline's Shivali Best visited Snap's offices in London this week to test them out herself.

item.title: Juvenile dinosaur nicknamed 'Ollie' is Australia's smallest sauropod
item.description: Nicknamed 'Ollie', the juvenile Diamantinasaurus matildae was identified by analysing fossils found by a sheep grazier in outback Queensland more than a decade ago.

item.title: Lost South American wildflower is rediscovered in the foothills of the Andes mountains
item.description: The orange wildflower was given the scientific name 'extinctus' because experts suspected it had died out following the widespread destruction of the Ecuadorian forest where it had been found.

item.title: Mathematicians prove the best way to get tangles out of hair is to start brushing at the ENDS
item.description: Harvard researchers created a model that simulated two entwined filaments to represent a tangle of hair, and analysed different ways of 'brushing' it so the hairs became free.

item.title: Tardigrades can hitch-hike on snails to travel longer distances
item.description: Tardigrades are one of the most indestructible life forms on Earth and can survive in outer space. But experts at Adam Mickiewicz University, Poland, found a possible weakness - snail mucus.

item.title: Newcastle is named the worst city in EUROPE for nitrogen dioxide pollution in March
item.description: Cleantech firm Airly uses sensors and AI-driven algorithms to study nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and particulate matter (PM10) elements of air pollution across European cities.

item.title: Jesus 'died of fatal bleeding caused by a dislocated shoulder from carrying the cross'
item.description: London-based retired neurologist Patrick Pullicino also believes he can explain why, as told in the Gospel of John, blood and water poured from Jesus Christ's crucified body.

item.title: Why humans live to 80 while giraffes die at 24: Animals with slower genetic mutations live longer
item.description: Researchers from the Wellcome Sanger Institute compared the genomes of 16 species and found animals with a slower rate of genetic changes have longer lifespans.

item.title: Decline in the availability of NITROGEN in could have dire consequences for plant and animal growth
item.description: A new study from the National Socio-environmental Sythesis Centre suggests that some parts of the world are experiencing a decline in the availability of nitrogen.

item.title: Cats know name of their owner and can recognise monikers of their feline friends, research shows
item.description: Authors, from Kyoto University, said the results suggest cats know each other's names and 'possibly' those of their owners.

item.title: Binary star system captured by two MAGIC telescopes
item.description: RS Ophiuchi (RS Oph) is in the constellation of the Serpent Bearer and is made up of a white dwarf and a red giant that is on the cusp of burning up in a supernova.

item.title: First all-private astronaut crew begin science experiments on the ISS
item.description: Axiom Space's Ax-1 mission includes three businessmen each paying $55 million for the ten day trip, and a former NASA astronaut acting as commander for Axiom.

item.title: Chinese-owned TikTok created an 'alternate universe' for Russia
item.description: Soon after Russian troops entered Ukraine on February 24, technology giants joined others in restricting access to its services in Russia and TikTok was no different.

item.title: Tinder launches FESTIVAL MODE that lets singletons find and match fellow festivalgoers
item.description: Tinder users can select which festivals they plan to attend, and will then be able to browse and match other users going as early as a month before the event.

item.title: People buy into fake news 'because they want to believe it is true'
item.description: People who consider how a lie might become true think it is less unethical to tell because they judge the lie's broader message, or the gist, as true enough, according to a London Business School study.

item.title: Meta plans to release the first version of its Star Trek-style smart glasses in 2024
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg has long spoken of his ambition to create a virtual world where humans can work, socialise and play, and his US company's much-anticipated AR glasses are just one part of this vision.

item.title: Scientists identify key traits of A**HOLES including manipulation, aggression, and entitlement
item.description: Scientists from the Franklin College of Arts and Sciences have revealed the key characteristics of a**holes - and say middle-aged men are most likely to have them.

item.title: Life on Earth appeared 3.75 billion years ago - 300 million years EARLIER than previously thought
item.description: Researchers at University College London have discovered a complex structure inside the rock - a stem with parallel branches - which they say is most likely biological in origin.

item.title: Monkey brains are influenced by social interactions, according to a study
item.description: A team of researchers from the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, studied the brains, and social interactions of a group of rhesus macaques living on Cayo Santiago.

item.title: Vegan dogs have fewer health disorders and are less likely to need medication
item.description: Researchers from the University of Winchester studied the diets of more than 2,500 dogs to understand the link between diet and health outcomes.

item.title: Will a robot take YOUR job? Scientists reveal the jobs at highest risk
item.description: Researchers from the Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne have revealed which jobs are most and least likely to be taken by robots.

item.title: Teens in a single parent household are 'more likely to show delinquent behaviour'
item.description: Teens who live in single-parent families are more likely to show 'delinquent' behaviours - even if the parent has a new partner living with them, report experts at Malmö University, Sweden.

item.title: European Space Agency scraps plans to work with Russia on future moon missions
item.description: The European Space Agency said it would no longer cooperate with Moscow's space agency Roscosmos on the science missions Luna 25, 26 or 27 because of the ongoing war in Ukraine.

item.title: How 2 million years of shifting climates shaped our evolution
item.description: Experts at Pusan National University in South Korea combined modelling data with fossil and archaeological analyses to study the movements of five hominin species over the past two million years.

item.title: Having a swell time! Kitesurfer tackles a 50ft wave in Portugal on an electric FLYING surfboard
item.description: New footage shows Tom Court, a British surfer mastering the waves using an efoil off the coast of Nazaré, Portugal.

item.title: There's only a 10% chance of limiting global warming to 2.7°F, study says
item.description: Researchers have analysed climate targets of 196 countries from the time of the Paris Agreement until the end of the COP26 meeting in Glasgow last year.

item.title: Hubble spots the 'ancestor of a supermassive black hole'
item.description: The research was carried out by an international team of experts, led by astrophysicists at the Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, and the Technical University of Denmark.

item.title: Saturn, Mars, Venus and Jupiter will line up in the pre-dawn sky this month
item.description: Starting April 17, the four planets will appear diagonally in the south-east, with Jupiter nearest the horizon and Saturn the highest.

item.title: 'Dead sunspot' has launched a fiery ball of plasma toward Earth
item.description: The explosive event happened on Monday, coming from a sunspot that was previously thought to be dead and no longer active, known as AR2987.

item.title: Largest earthquake in HISTORY hit northern Chile 3,800 years ago and caused a huge tsunami
item.description: Researchers from the University of Southampton say the earthquake had a magnitude of around 9.5 and caused a tsunami that travelled more than 5,000 miles to New Zealand.

item.title: Chocolate poisonings in dogs are expected to increase by 54% this Easter, vets warn
item.description: New data from The Kennel Club shows that chocolate poisonings in dogs are expected to increase by 54 per cent this month.

item.title: Cod and chips off the menu? Popular fish will become harder to catch amid rising sea temperatures
item.description: Researchers from Rutgers University have warned that rising sea temperatures will mean fewer popular fish species will be available to catch over the next 200 years.

item.title: Zoom calls get louder when the display gets blurry, study finds
item.description: Humans use hand gestures when it's hard for others to hear us, but we also speak louder when it's hard for people to see us, report experts at Radboud University, the Netherlands.

item.title: Amazon customers in the US can donate $1 to plant a tree using Alexa
item.description: The new skill has been launched in celebration of Earth Month, with the reforestation charity organizing tree planting in places it will do the most good around the world.

item.title: Fitbit gets approval to be used to monitor passive heart rhythms and identify atrial fibrillation
item.description: Google said the PPG AFib algorithm, available within the Fitbit app, assess users' heart rhythms while they are sleeping, and alert them if they suffer from AFib.

item.title: UK is to build 'brain' of the world's biggest radio telescope
item.description: From its headquarters in the UK the Square Kilometre Array Observatory is set to explore the evolution of the early Universe and delve into the formation of our own Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: Record-breaking 'megacomet' is more than 80 MILES wide, NASA reveals
item.description: The comet, called C/2014 UN271 (Bernardinelli-Bernstein), was first discovered back in 2010, but its size has only been confirmed today.

item.title: What is a Pink Full Moon? Lunar phase set to dominate sky over Easter weekend
item.description: It will appear a goldish color and is also known as the Paschal Moon, from which the date of Easter is calculated in the Christian calendar.

item.title: Anonymous leaks massive trove of Kremlin files and vows to continue hacking Russia
item.description: Anonymous has already launched a series of cyber attacks in retaliation for Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine, including a data leak of Russian soldiers and takeovers of state-controlled TV.

item.title: Scientists reveal what gives sausages their 'crunch' - and it could lead to better vegan options
item.description: Scientists from the Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research compared meat, vegan and vegetarian sausages at a molecular level to understand what gives meat sausages texture.

item.title: NASA shows off its Psyche spacecraft that will fly beyond Mars to explore a strange asteroid
item.description: Engineers are putting the final touches on the probe, which is set to launch from Cape Canaveral, Florida, in August on its journey to a metal-rich asteroid of the same name.

item.title: NASA is testing futuristic spacesuits with built-in cooling systems
item.description: In a new video, NASA has shown how astronauts are conducting spacewalks just outside of the ISS while receiving cooled water from an on-board machine.

item.title: Electric foiling raceboat takes flight for first time on River Po ahead of its race debut in 2023
item.description: The electric RaceBird prototype completed its first test flight on the River Po close to San Nazzaro in northern Italy.

item.title: Robot nose can distinguish between different WHISKIES - and could replace trained sommeliers
item.description: Scientists from the University of Technology Sydney have developed a robotic nose called NOS.E that can distinguish between different brands, origins and styles by 'sniffing' the liquor.

item.title: Working from home part-time could harm the environment, study says
item.description: People who work from home at least once or twice a week live further away than those who work in the office full-time, report researchers at the University of Sussex in Brighton.

item.title: Pop-up igloo inspired by polar bears has an origami 'skin' to trap snow and use it as an insulator
item.description: A team of students from the Royal Danish Academy has developed a pop-up igloo inspired by polar bears, with an origami 'skin' to trap snow and use it as a natural insulator.

item.title: Achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 IS possible without damaging the economy, study claims
item.description: Scientists from University College London modelled various scenarios to see if the ambitious target is possible with disrupting economic growth.

item.title: Naps are beneficial to children right up until the age of FIVE and could boost reading skills
item.description: Researchers from Macquarie University in Australia found that daytime naps can benefit children's ability to map letters to sounds - an important indicator of early reading skills.

item.title: Gene-edited cats could stop owners sneezing by slashing protein that triggers allergy
item.description: Catlovers who are allergic could soon have a gene-edited pet which does not make them sneeze. (file photo)

item.title: Smart BRA with built-in ultrasound technology can detect early signs of breast cancer
item.description: The smart bra features small ultrasound sensors in the lining, and was developed by Nextwear Technology, a wearables firm based in Abuja, Nigeria.

item.title: Astronomers reveal clearest image yet of mysterious 'odd radio circle'
item.description: There are now three leading theories about what causes 'odd radio circles' thanks to the new images captured by the South African Radio Astronomy Observatory's MeerKat radio telescope.

item.title: Billions of genetically modified male mosquitos will be released in California and Florida
item.description: Oxitec, a biological pest control development firm, produced the edited version of the flying insects to combat mosquito-borne diseases like Dengue fever and Zika.

item.title: Weeds including ragwort are TWICE as likely to attract bees than wildflowers, study finds
item.description: Researchers from the University of Sussex have revealed how these 'dangerous' plants are twice as likely to attract bees than wildflowers.

item.title: Astronomers may have spotted the afterglow from a 'kilonova' explosion
item.description: Kilonovas are immense explosions caused by neutron stars colliding into each other, sending an intense jet of of high-energy particles through space, experts in Evanston, Illinois explain.

item.title: Ukraine nuclear power plant incident is NOT another Chernobyl, experts say
item.description: The Zaporizhzhia power plant was hit by Russian shelling early Friday, sparking a fire in a building just outside the main complex and raising fears of a Chernobyl-like nuclear disaster.

item.title: NASA invites public to add their names to a database that will orbit the moon on Artemis 1
item.description: The US space agency will send the Orion capsule atop a Space Launch System (SLS) mega rocket at some point this summer, possibly as early as late May.

item.title: Artificial intelligence model can detect mental health conditions on Reddit
item.description: A team of computer scientists from Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire set about training an AI model to analyze social media texts.

item.title: TikTok ditches its three minute limit and will now let users post videos up to 10 minutes long
item.description: The expanded video length will allow users of the Chinese social network more flexibility when filming clips such as beauty tutorials, cooking demos and comedic sketches.

item.title: Solar panels successfully grow spinach by pulling in water vapour, experts report
item.description: A new system, called WEC2P, consists of solar panels coated with hydrogel - a kind of squishy water loving polymer, researchers in Thuwal, Saudi Arabia report.

item.title: Entrepreneurs like Elon Musk and Richard Branson are more likely to have a symmetrical face
item.description: Although having prominent cheekbones makes people more likely to become an entrepreneur, it has no bearing on whether they will be a successful one, according to University of Cyprus-led researchers.

item.title: NatWest and RBS banking apps are back up following two-hour outage
item.description: According to Down Detector, the issues started at around 08:48 GMT today, and have just been resolved.

item.title: Teenagers' report tics affected by increased social media use during Covid pandemic
item.description: Half of respondents said that increased online activity during the pandemic had made their condition more severe but an expert said more research is still needed.

item.title: Astronomers create detailed images of the largest shockwave in the universe
item.description: These gigantic shock waves are larger than our entire galaxy, and form when clusters of galaxies collide, according to the researchers led by the University of Hamburg in Germany.

item.title: NASA's Artemis 1 mission and first launch of the SLS mega rocket won't lift off until at least May
item.description: It is set to lift off atop the massive Space Launch System (SLS) megarocket from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, but has been hit by a number of delays.

item.title: Russian space agency boss warns against sanctions that could block cooperation on the ISS
item.description: Roscosmos Director General Dmitry Rogozin posted a long thread on Twitter, complaining about President Joe Biden's threat of sanctions against the Russian space program.

item.title: Elusive variety of snowdrop is discovered in a garden in Northamptonshire after more than 50 years
item.description: The stunning variety was spotted in the grounds of the 1,000-acre Courteenhall estate in Northamptonshire, after which it is named.

item.title: China's Yutu-2 rover spots two spheres of glass on the moon
item.description: China's Yutu-2 rover has spotted two intact spheres of translucent glass up to an inch thick on the far side of the moon, according to researchers from Guangzhou who described the new finding.

item.title: Stunningly photos from John Glenn's first orbit of Earth released to mark 60th anniversary
item.description: The images show Glenn at key stages of the mission in detail never seen before, thanks to processing and remastering transfers of the flight film.

item.title: California project launched to cover a network of canals with solar panels
item.description: Project Nexus will cover segments in Stanislaus County near Modesto, producing enough power for 100,000 homes, with work due to start this fall and finish in 2024.

item.title: NASA's Curiosity rover captures footage of the Martian sky with clouds of carbon dioxide ice
item.description: Martian clouds are very faint in the atmosphere, so special imaging techniques have been used by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, in Pasadena, California, to create the footage.

item.title: Literature: 90% of English medieval chivalry and heroism manuscripts have been LOST, study finds
item.description: Researchers from Oxford University have analysed the survival of medieval stories across Europe, and found extremely varying results.

item.title: Elon Musk-owned Neuralink confirms monkeys died during tests but rejects abuse claim
item.description: Neuralink has hit back at the claims of abuse, calling out animal rights group, Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine (PCRM), as oppose any use of animals in research.

item.title: Meet the dual-gender stick insect that is half-male and half-female
item.description: Named Charlie, the green bean stick insect from Waldringfield, Suffolk, is the 'first reported gynandromorph' in that species according to experts at London's Natural History Museum.

item.title: Ancient crocodile's last meal was a dinosaur, study reveals
item.description: The fossilised bones were recovered from a sheep station near the north western margins of the Winton Formation, a geological deposit in Queensland.

item.title: Astronomers in Germany have discovered a 'strange' new type of star
item.description: It's thought that this new type of star was formed by the merger of two white dwarfs - the hot, dense remnants of long-dead stars, report scientists in Tübingen, Germany.

item.title: Levels of methane in the atmosphere are growing 'dangerously fast', warn scientists
item.description: A report, published in Nature, saw an international team examine data gathered by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) throughout 2021.

item.title: Neuroscience: Forgetting is a form of LEARNING that helps us access more important information
item.description: 'Lost' memories are not really gone, just made inaccessible, researchers from from Trinity College Dublin and the University of Toronto have argued.

item.title: Geology: Mountain-sized ROCK beneath southern Japan could be acting as a 'magnet' for megaquakes
item.description: Seismic data collected over the course of 20 years was run through a supercomputer by researchers led from the University of Texas at Austin to produce the first full model of the body.

item.title: Genetics: Love of nature is partially in your genes, study reveals
item.description: A survey of 1,153 pairs of adult twins in the United Kingdom was undertaken by researchers from the National University of Singapore and the University of Queensland.

item.title: Megafauna: Ice Age mammoth, rhino, hyena and wolf dating back up to 60,000 years unearthed in Devon
item.description: The remains were found underground during pre-construction surveys at Sherford New Town, a 5,500-home community being developed on the edge of Plymouth.

item.title: Warming climate and intensive agriculture have HALVED insect populations in some parts of the world
item.description: UCL researchers studied records of 20,000 insect species and found that in areas with high-intensity agriculture and climate warming, the number of insects was 49% lower than in natural habitats.

item.title: Using smartphone for an hour less a day makes you less anxious and more satisfied, study says
item.description: Past studies have shown that smartphone use is linked to obesity, neck pain and addictive behaviour, so Ruhr-Universität Bochum experts set out to establish just how much use is too much.

item.title: You can save £100 on this highly-rated affordable robot vacuum cleaner on sale on Amazon
item.description: According to over 600 impressive five-star reviews, the Lefant M213 Robot Vacuum Cleaner performs just as well as premium priced robot vacuums but at a much more reasonable price.

item.title: Samsung's next smartphone could feature a transparent ROLLABLE screen, patent suggests
item.description: Aa new patent suggests that Samsung could be looking beyond foldables, and could soon launch a smartphone with a transparent, rollable screen.

item.title: NASA Artems Astronauts transfer vehicles unveiled by the space agency
item.description: The futuristic pod-shaped transport vehicles were developed for NASA by Canoo Technologies from Bentonville, Arkansas.

item.title: Scientists discover a 'slimmer' type of red giant that 'is having mass sucked away'
item.description: The University of Sydney researchers found not just one but a smattering of 40 slimmer red giants hidden amongst 'a sea of normal ones'.

item.title: Nearly a third of e-scooter riders who end up in A&E have a fracture or dislocation
item.description: The figures, based on 311 attendances over a two-year period at a Finnish hospital, showed that nearly a third of cases - 31 per cent - involved a fracture or dislocation.

item.title: Hay fever warning issued as the Met Office predicts high pollen levels over Easter weekend
item.description: The Met Office has revealed that pollen levels are expected to be high across most of England and Wales over the Easter weekend.

item.title: Volocopter completes maiden flight of its fully electric VoloCity air taxi
item.description: The electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) vehicle, made by German company Volocopter, looks like a giant drone with 18 rotors, and has a top speed of 68 mph.

item.title: This Echo Dot and Ring Video Doorbell bundle is 55% off
item.description: If you like a bargain, you'll love this Amazon Easter weekend deal. Today you can buy a Ring Video Doorbell Wired and an Amazon Echo Dot (3rd Gen) for under £40.

item.title: Alignment of Jupiter and Neptune could bring good fortune for months, astrologers say
item.description: Jupiter and Neptune align every 13 years, but their meeting yesterday in the constellation of Pisces - where they are most 'at home' - last happened in 1856.

item.title: Caviar could be available for all after scientists grow luxury dish in lab
item.description: Scientists, from the firm Caviar Biotec and University College London, have now managed to grow the fish eggs in only 40 days.

item.title: Supernova that triggered birth of the solar system is recreated in lab
item.description: Molecular clouds, like the one that contained the building blocks that led to the Sun and planets, can remain in a state of peaceful equilibrium forever, if left alone. But a supernova shockwave hit.

item.title: Meteor that hit Earth in 2014 was from another star system, scientists say
item.description: In a newly-released memo, US Space Command officials have said that a rocky body that lit up the skies near Manus Island, Papua New Guinea in 2014 'was indeed an interstellar object'.

item.title: Lab-grown exotic meat such as tiger steaks and lion burgers could soon be on British dinner tables
item.description: London-based Primeval Foods wants to host tasting sessions at Michelin-starred restaurants in the city to show off its 'cultivated' products, which are grown from animal cells.

item.title: Netflix introduces a 'Double Thumbs Up' button to let users flag when they really LOVE a show
item.description: The Double Thumbs Up button lets users flag the content they have really loved watching, so the platform can serve up more of the same via their personalised recommendations.

item.title: How cuckoos make their eggs look like those of other birds to trick them into raising their young
item.description: Cuckoo finches inherit their ability to mimic the appearance of their hosts' eggs from their mothers - not from their fathers, a new study from University of Cambridge experts reveals.

item.title: Wind turbines 'taking deadly toll on migrating birds': Map highlights 'collision hotspots'
item.description: Researchers from the University of East Anglia looked at GPS data from 65 bird tracking studies to work out where they fly at 'danger height', said to be 15 to 135 metres above wind turbines

item.title: Gang members who offend together are likely to violently turn on each OTHER, study finds
item.description: Researchers from the University of Cambridge studied 16 years of data from Thames Valley Police in the hopes of understanding patterns of violence within UK organised crime gangs.

item.title: Rhesus monkeys 'can perceive their own heartbeats'
item.description: University of California, Davis experts say their findings could support future psychiatric research because impairments in interoception are linked to anxiety, depression, and Alzheimer's.

item.title: Magic mushroom compound 'opens up depressed people's brains'
item.description: Researchers at the Imperial Centre for Psychedelic Research in London suggest the findings indicate that psilocybin could be a real alternative approach to depression treatments.

item.title: Scientists discover a brain circuit that boosts maths skills in children
item.description: The circuit triggers an area near the back of the head known as the IPS (intraparietal sulcus), which is involved in processing figures, according to experts at Stanford University.

item.title: Sharks don't bother wasting time chasing after prey they are unlikely to catch, study finds
item.description: Researchers from Flinders University studied Port Jackson sharks and found the animals don't chase prey if they are unlikely to catch them.

item.title: Children think eating animals is 'less morally acceptable than adults'
item.description: Children differ dramatically from adults in their moral views on animals, new research from the University of Exeter shows.

item.title: Massive lunar impact 4.3 billion years ago may explain why the moon's far side is more cratered
item.description: The immense heat from the impact would have melted the moon's mantle and carried elements to the nearside, which would have produced lava flows, according to a Brown University-led study.

item.title: NASA to test SpinLaunch's 'whirl 'n' hurl' space launch technology
item.description: NASA and SpinLaunch - a startup based in Long Beach, California - have signed an agreement to fly a payload using SpinLaunch's bizarre mass accelerator launch system.
